refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A Formation resource allows you to combine spacecraft in a “container” object and then GMAT’s propagation subsystem will model the collection of spacecraft as a coupled dynamic system. You can only propagate Formation resources using numerical-integrator type propagators. This resource cannot be modified in the Mission Sequence.

entry.para: Adds a list of Spacecraft to the Formation. The list cannot be empty.

Allows you to set available colors on orbits of spacecrafts that are in formation flight. The orbit colors can be identified through a string or an integer array. For example: Setting a formation's orbit color to red can be done in following two ways: Formation1.OrbitColor = Red or Formation1.OrbitColor = [255 0 0]. This field can be modified in the Mission Sequence as well.

listitem.para: Any color available from the Orbit Color selectbox

entry.para: Allows you to select available colors for perturbing trajectories of spacecrafts in the Formation during iterative processes such as Differential Correction or Optimization. The target color can be identified through a string or an integer array. For example: Setting a formation's perturbing trajectories to yellow color can be done in following two ways: Formation1.TargetColor = Yellow or Formation1.TargetColor = [255 255 0] . This field can be modified in the Mission Sequence as well.

listitem.para: Any color available from the Target Color selectbox

refsection.title: GUI
refsection.para: To create a simple Formation and configure its Spacecraft, in the Resource Tree:

listitem.para: Right-click the Spacecraft folder and select Add Spacecraft.
Right click the Formations folder and select Add Formation.
Double-click Formation1 to open its dialog box.
Click the right-arrow button twice to add DefaultSC and Spacecraft1 to Formation1.

note.para: A Spacecraft can only be added to one Formation.

refsection.title: Remarks
refsection.para: A Formation is a container object that allows you to model a group of Spacecraft as a coupled system. You can add Spacecraft to a Formation using the Add field as shown in the script examples below or in the GUI example above. The primary reasons to use a Formation Resource are (1) to simplify the propagation of multiple spacecraft and (2) for performance reasons. GMAT’s propagation subsystem models Formations as a coupled dynamic system. Once spacecraft have been added to a Formation, you can easily propagate all of the spacecraft by simply including the formation in the Propagate command statement like this:
You can only propagate Formation resources using numerical-integrator type propagators. GMAT does not support propagation of the orbit state transition matrix when propagating formations.
When propagating a Formation, all spacecraft in the Formation must have equivalent epochs. GMAT will allow you to separately propagate a Spacecraft that has been added to a Formation, like this:
However, when a Formation is propagated, if the epochs of all Spacecraft in the Formation are not equivalent to a tolerance of a few microseconds, GMAT will throw an error and execution will stop.

refsection.title: Setting Colors On a Formation of Spacecrafts
refsection.para: GMAT allows you to assign orbit colors to a Formation resource that may contain number of spacecrafts. The Formation of spacecrafts is drawn using the OrbitView graphics display window. GMAT also allows you to assign colors to perturbing trajectories of spacecrafts in the Formation during iterative processes such as Differential Correction or Optimization. The Formation object’s OrbitColor and TargetColor fields are used to assign colors to both orbital and perturbing trajectories of spacecrafts in formation flight. See the section to learn more about these two fields.
